introduction.title: C# Introduction
paragraphs: What is C#?
C# is pronounced "C-Sharp".
It is an object-oriented programming language created by Microsoft that runs on the .NET Framework.
C# has roots from the C family, and the language is close to other popular languages like C++ and Java.
The first version was released in year 2002.
The latest version, C# 13, was released in November 2024.

sections.name: uses
sections.heading: C# is used for:
list: Mobile applications
Desktop applications
Web applications
Web services
Web sites
Games
VR
Database applications
And much, much more!

sections.name: why-use
sections.heading: Why Use C#?
list: It is one of the most popular programming languages in the world
It is easy to learn and simple to use
It has huge community support
C# is an object-oriented language which gives a clear structure to programs and allows code to be reused, lowering development costs
As C# is close to C, C++ and Java, it makes it easy for programmers to switch to C# or vice versa

sections.name: get-started
sections.heading: Get Started
paragraphs: This tutorial will teach you the basics of C#.
It is not necessary to have any prior programming experience.
Get Started »

get-started.title: C# Get Started
paragraphs: C# IDE
The easiest way to get started with C# is to use an IDE.
An IDE (Integrated Development Environment) is used to edit and compile code.

sections.name: ide
sections.heading: C# IDE
paragraphs: In our tutorial, we will use Visual Studio Community, which is free to download from https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/vs/community/.
Applications written in C# use the .NET Framework, so it makes sense to use Visual Studio, as the program, the framework, and the language, are all created by Microsoft.

sections.name: install
sections.heading: C# Install
paragraphs: Once the Visual Studio Installer is downloaded and installed, choose the .NET workload and click on the Modify/Install button.
After the installation is complete, click on the Launch button to get started with Visual Studio.

sections.name: create-project
sections.heading: Create a New Project
paragraphs: On the start window, choose Create a new project.
Then click on the "Install more tools and features" link.
Choose "Console App (.NET Core)" from the list and click on the Next button.
Enter a name for your project, and click on the Create button.
Visual Studio will automatically generate some code for your project.

paragraphs: C# Syntax
In the previous chapter, we created a C# file called Program.cs, and we used the following code to print "Hello World" to the screen:

sections.name: example
sections.heading: Example

sections.name: explained
sections.heading: Example explained
paragraphs: Line 1: using System means that we can use classes from the System namespace.
Line 2: A blank line. C# ignores white space. However, multiple lines makes the code more readable.
Line 3: namespace is used to organize your code, and it is a container for classes and other namespaces.
Line 4: The curly braces {} marks the beginning and the end of a block of code.
Line 5: class is a container for data and methods, which brings functionality to your program. Every line of code that runs in C# must be inside a class. In our example, we named the class Program.

Don't worry if you don't understand how using System, namespace and class works. Just think of it as something that (almost) always appears in your program, and that you will learn more about them in a later chapter.

Line 7: Another thing that always appear in a C# program is the Main method. Any code inside its curly brackets {} will be executed. You don't have to understand the keywords before and after Main. You will get to know them bit by bit while reading this tutorial.
Line 9: Console is a class of the System namespace, which has a WriteLine() method that is used to output/print text. In our example, it will output "Hello World!".
If you omit the using System line, you would have to write System.Console.WriteLine() to print/output text.

sections.name: notes
sections.heading: Notes
list: Every C# statement ends with a semicolon ;.
C# is case-sensitive; "MyClass" and "myclass" have different meaning.
Unlike Java, the name of the C# file does not have to match the class name, but they often do (for better organization).

output.title: C# Output
paragraphs: C# Output
To output values or print text in C#, you can use the WriteLine() method:

sections.name: writeline
sections.heading: WriteLine()
paragraphs: To output values or print text in C#, you can use the WriteLine() method.
sections.example: Console.WriteLine("Hello World!");

sections.name: multiple-lines
sections.heading: Multiple WriteLine()
paragraphs: You can add as many WriteLine() methods as you want.
It will add a new line for each method.

sections.name: numbers
sections.heading: Output Numbers
paragraphs: You can also output numbers, and perform mathematical calculations:
sections.example: Console.WriteLine(3 + 3);

sections.name: write-method
sections.heading: The Write Method
paragraphs: There is also a Write() method, which is similar to WriteLine().
The only difference is that it does not insert a new line at the end of the output.
sections.example:
Console.Write("Hello World! ");
Console.Write("I will print on the same line.");
sections.note: We add an extra space when needed (after "Hello World!" in the example above), for better readability.

sections.name: tutorial-note
sections.heading: Note
paragraphs: In this tutorial, we will only use WriteLine() as it makes it easier to read the output of code.

comments.title: C# Comments
paragraphs: C# Comments
Comments can be used to explain C# code, and to make it more readable.
It can also be used to prevent execution when testing alternative code.

sections.name: single-line
sections.heading: Single-line Comments
paragraphs: Single-line comments start with two forward slashes (//).
Any text between // and the end of the line is ignored by C# (will not be executed).
This example uses a single-line comment before a line of code:
sections.example:
// This is a comment
Console.WriteLine("Hello World!");

sections.name: single-line-end
sections.heading: Single-line Comment at the End of a Line
paragraphs: This example uses a single-line comment at the end of a line of code:
sections.example: Console.WriteLine("Hello World!");  // This is a comment

sections.name: multi-line
sections.heading: C# Multi-line Comments
paragraphs: Multi-line comments start with /* and ends with */.
Any text between /* and */ will be ignored by C#.
This example uses a multi-line comment (a comment block) to explain the code:

sections.name: single-vs-multi
sections.heading: Single or multi-line comments?
paragraphs: It is up to you which you want to use.
Normally, we use // for short comments, and /* */ for longer.

exercise.question: What symbol is used to start a single-line comment in C#?

variables.title: C# Variables
paragraphs: C# Variables
Variables are containers for storing data values.
In C#, there are different types of variables (defined with different keywords).

sections.name: types
sections.heading: Variable Types
paragraphs: Examples of variable types in C#:
list: int - stores integers (whole numbers), without decimals, such as 123 or -123
double - stores floating point numbers, with decimals, such as 19.99 or -19.99
char - stores single characters, such as 'a' or 'B'. Char values are surrounded by single quotes
string - stores text, such as "Hello World". String values are surrounded by double quotes
bool - stores values with two states: true or false

data-types.title: C# Data Types
paragraphs: C# Data Types
As explained in the variables chapter, a variable in C# must be a specified data type.

sections.name: example
sections.heading: Example
sections.example:
int myNum = 5;               // Integer (whole number)
double myDoubleNum = 5.99D;  // Floating point number
char myLetter = 'D';         // Character
bool myBool = true;          // Boolean
string myText = "Hello";     // String

sections.name: about
sections.heading: What is a Data Type?
paragraphs: A data type specifies the size and type of variable values.
It is important to use the correct data type for the corresponding variable; to avoid errors, to save time and memory, but it will also make your code more maintainable and readable.

rows: Stores fractional numbers. Sufficient for storing 6 to 7 decimal digits
Stores fractional numbers. Sufficient for storing 15 decimal digits
Stores a single character/letter, surrounded by single quotes
Stores a sequence of characters, surrounded by double quotes

sections.name: numbers
sections.heading: Numbers
paragraphs: Number types are divided into two groups:
Integer types stores whole numbers, positive or negative (such as 123 or -456), without decimals. Valid types are int and long.
Floating point types represents numbers with a fractional part, containing one or more decimals. Valid types are float and double.
The most used for numbers are int (for whole numbers) and double (for floating point numbers).

sections.name: int
sections.heading: Int
paragraphs: The int data type can store whole numbers from -2147483648 to 2147483647.
In general, the int data type is the preferred data type when we create variables with a numeric value.
sections.example:
int myNum = 100000;
Console.WriteLine(myNum);

sections.name: long
sections.heading: Long
paragraphs: The long data type can store whole numbers from -9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807.
This is used when int is not large enough to store the value.
You should end the value with an "L".
sections.example:
long myNum = 15000000000L;
Console.WriteLine(myNum);

sections.name: floating-point
sections.heading: Floating Point Types
paragraphs: You should use a floating point type whenever you need a number with a decimal, such as 9.99 or 3.14515.
The float and double data types can store fractional numbers.
End the value with an "F" for floats and "D" for doubles.

sections.name: float-vs-double
sections.heading: Use float or double?
paragraphs: The precision of a floating point value indicates how many digits the value can have after the decimal point.
The precision of float is only six or seven decimal digits, while double variables have a precision of about 15 digits.
Therefore it is safer to use double for most calculations.

sections.name: scientific
sections.heading: Scientific Numbers
paragraphs: A floating point number can also be a scientific number with an "e" to indicate the power of 10:

sections.name: booleans
sections.heading: Booleans
paragraphs: A boolean data type is declared with the bool keyword and can only take the values true or false:
sections.note: Boolean values are mostly used for conditional testing.

sections.name: characters
sections.heading: Characters
paragraphs: The char data type is used to store a single character.
The character must be surrounded by single quotes, like 'A' or 'c':
sections.example:
char myGrade = 'B';
Console.WriteLine(myGrade);

sections.name: strings
sections.heading: Strings
paragraphs: The string data type is used to store a sequence of characters (text).
String values must be surrounded by double quotes:
sections.example:
string greeting = "Hello World";
Console.WriteLine(greeting);

type-casting.title: C# Type Casting
paragraphs: C# Type Casting
Type casting is when you assign a value of one data type to another type.
In C#, there are two types of casting:

sections.name: types
sections.heading: Types of Casting
list: Implicit Casting (automatically) - converting a smaller type to a larger type size
char -> int -> long -> float -> double
Explicit Casting (manually) - converting a larger type to a smaller size type
double -> float -> long -> int -> char

sections.name: implicit
sections.heading: Implicit Casting
paragraphs: Implicit casting is done automatically when passing a smaller size type to a larger size type:
sections.example:
int myInt = 9;
double myDouble = myInt;       // Automatic casting: int to double

Console.WriteLine(myInt);      // Outputs 9
Console.WriteLine(myDouble);   // Outputs 9

sections.name: explicit
sections.heading: Explicit Casting
paragraphs: Explicit casting must be done manually by placing the type in parentheses in front of the value:
sections.example:
double myDouble = 9.78;
int myInt = (int) myDouble;    // Manual casting: double to int

Console.WriteLine(myDouble);   // Outputs 9.78
Console.WriteLine(myInt);      // Outputs 9

sections.name: conversion-methods
sections.heading: Type Conversion Methods
paragraphs: It is also possible to convert data types explicitly by using built-in methods, such as Convert.ToBoolean, Convert.ToDouble, Convert.ToString, Convert.ToInt32 (int) and Convert.ToInt64 (long):

sections.name: why
sections.heading: Why Conversion?
paragraphs: Many times, there's no need for type conversion.
But sometimes you have to.
Take a look at the next chapter, when working with user input, to see an example of this.

exercise.question: What is implicit casting in C#?
options: Manually converting one type to another.
Automatically converting a smaller type to a larger type size.
exercise.answer: Automatically converting a smaller type to a larger type size.

math.title: C# Math
paragraphs: C# Math
The C# Math class has many methods that allows you to perform mathematical tasks on numbers.

sections.name: max
sections.heading: Math.Max(x,y)
paragraphs: The Math.Max(x,y) method can be used to find the highest value of x and y:
sections.example: Math.Max(5, 10);

sections.name: min
sections.heading: Math.Min(x,y)
paragraphs: The Math.Min(x,y) method can be used to find the lowest value of of x and y:
sections.example: Math.Min(5, 10);

sections.name: sqrt
sections.heading: Math.Sqrt(x)
paragraphs: The Math.Sqrt(x) method returns the square root of x:
sections.example: Math.Sqrt(64);

sections.name: abs
sections.heading: Math.Abs(x)
paragraphs: The Math.Abs(x) method returns the absolute (positive) value of x:
sections.example: Math.Abs(-4.7);

sections.name: round
sections.heading: Math.Round()
paragraphs: Math.Round() rounds a number to the nearest whole number:
sections.example: Math.Round(9.99);

strings.title: C# Strings
paragraphs: C# Strings
Strings are used for storing text.
A string variable contains a collection of characters surrounded by double quotes:

sections.name: create-string
sections.heading: Create a String
paragraphs: Create a variable of type string and assign it a value:
sections.example: string greeting = "Hello";

sections.name: many-words
sections.heading: String with Many Words
paragraphs: A string variable can contain many words, if you want:
sections.example: string greeting2 = "Nice to meet you!";

sections.name: length
sections.heading: String Length
paragraphs: A string in C# is actually an object, which contain properties and methods that can perform certain operations on strings.
The length of a string can be found with the Length property:
sections.example:
string txt = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ";
Console.WriteLine("The length of the txt string is: " + txt.Length);

sections.heading: Other Methods
